titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 919: Hymni cum glossis

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Ms. Codex 919: Hymni cum glossis are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Collection of hymns with marginal annotations about poetic devices; a poem (possibly nonsensical) about Joannes Benssius of Rotenburg, a teacher, and the possible compiler of the hymns; a copy of Sermon 30 from the pseudo-Augustinian Sermones ad heremitas, inserted in the middle of the poem; a manual for letter writing based on Cicero's De officiis and Sallust; and a poem praising the visitation of the Virgin Mary.

msItem.title: Sermo sancti augustini ad eremitas fratres de confessione, f. 48r
Manuductio sequitur epistolae in eadem, f. 49r
Carmen hystoriale de gloriose virginis Marie visitatione, f. 54r

support.watermark: On manuscript pages: Briquet Tete de Bœuf 14583 (1478), Briquet Tete de Bœuf 15374 (1488). On front and back fly leaves: watermarks similar to Churchill 96 (1799) and Churchill 133 (1755); both are 18th century Dutch watermarks.

supportDesc.extent: 55 leaves : 205 x 155 mm. bound to 208 x 165 mm

collation.p: Paper; i + 55 + i; 1¹⁴ 2-3¹⁶ 4⁹(+2); [1-55]; modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto.

layoutDesc.layout: Work 1 written in 15 long lines; work 2 written in 14 long lines; work 4 written in 18 long lines; work 5 written in 16 long lines.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in various scripts, including secretary cursive, later German cursive, and a Gothic script for section headings and titles.

origin.p: Written in Germany, possibly Leipzig, in the late 15th century (Zacour-Hirsch).
